;警方称，一名年轻的佛罗里达州母亲因涉嫌利用模仿网站雇佣杀手杀死她三岁的儿子而被捕。

;

;18 岁的 Jazmin Paez 面临教唆谋杀和非法使用通讯设备的指控。

;

;她被指控登录rentahitman.com 寻找刺客，甚至提交了一份根据 NBC 迈阿密获得的法庭文件，她的孩子的照片以及他的确切下落。

;

;据称，她希望在周末之前完成这项工作。

;

;网站所有者罗伯特·英尼斯 (Robert Innes) 向调查人员通报了佩兹的阴谋。他说，虽然他每天都会收到数百个杀手请求（其中许多是笑话），但帕兹的请求太真实了。

;

;“能够研究姓名和地址并验证预定目标是否位于特定地址，”Innes 告诉 NBC 迈阿密。这对我来说是一个危险信号。如果这些信息得到证实，对我来说，这就是需要考虑的事情，这就是我提到它的原因。”

;

;据当局称，该网站创始人创建该平台是为了抓获并遏制那些想要雇佣杀手的人。

;

;Paez 最终通过该网站与一名冒充杀手的调查员取得了联系。据哥伦比亚广播公司新闻报道，她愿意支付 3,000 美元来谋杀她三岁的儿子。从那里，当局能够追踪到用于提出请求并确认属于 Paez 的计算机的 IP。

;

;警方称，美国男子雇佣了杀害女友的凶手，并将谋杀归咎于反亚裔仇恨

;

;在与孩子的祖母交谈后，她确认他就是提交给网站的照片中的男孩，当局突然逮捕了他的母亲。

;

;她被关押在迈阿密戴德监狱，但后来在美国被释放据 NBC 迈阿密报道，保释金为 50,000 美元。

;

;她的儿子目前很安全，并由家人照顾。

;乌克兰表示，任何前往俄罗斯港口的船只都可能成为军事目标，这是对莫斯科威胁的针锋相对的回应，这种威胁加剧了全球粮食市场的战争风险。

;

;自从莫斯科停止允许乌克兰出口部分粮食收成的黑海协议以来，俄罗斯袭击了乌克兰的粮食储存设施，并警告说，所有前往乌克兰港口的船只都将被视为潜在的军事物资运输船.

;

;对重要的黑海贸易的威胁不断升级，增加了从石油、主食到化肥的全球市场动荡的风险。俄罗斯对其邻国的袭击已经严重扰乱了谷物和植物油主要生产国乌克兰的出口。

;

;乌克兰此前曾在黑海袭击过俄罗斯船只，在俄罗斯入侵后不久，乌克兰就用海王星反舰导弹击沉了旗舰莫斯科巡洋舰。

;

;2022 年 3 月，乌克兰还在别尔江斯克港击沉了一艘登陆舰，并损坏了另一艘，乌克兰的火箭弹已到达俄罗斯的主要补给线。克里米亚、刻赤海峡大桥。

;

;“莫斯科号巡洋舰的命运证明乌克兰国防军拥有击退俄罗斯海上侵略所需的手段，”乌克兰国防部表示。

;

;黑海也是俄罗斯主要石油码头的所在地，每天有超过 50 万桶原油流经新罗西斯克，这里也是化肥、谷物和煤炭的重要港口。油价变化不大，表明市场对中断的前景持怀疑态度。

;

;俄罗斯在克里米亚东部对面的塔曼附近也有几个成品油出口码头。彭博社监测的油轮跟踪数据显示，附近有 28 艘油轮，其中大部分是小型产品运输船。

;

;泽连斯基表示，乌克兰粮食交易可以在没有俄罗斯的情况下进行

;

;总部位于圣彼得堡的租船公司 Sea Lines 的首席执行官亚历山大·库利科夫表示，新罗西斯克港口周四照常工作。

;

;自克里米亚大桥爆炸以来，刻赤海峡的通道已被关闭，目前尚不清楚何时关闭。他说，它将重新开放。他说，他有两艘船正等待从南侧通过刻赤海峡。

;

;新罗西斯克港发言人没有立即回复置评请求。

;

;目前尚不清楚乌克兰的威胁有多现实。俄罗斯国防部也没有具体说明将如何对待任何试图进入乌克兰港口的船只。

;

;另一方面，俄罗斯在黑海北部和亚速海的防御能力相当可观。其中包括一支战舰舰队，其中包括导弹巡洋舰和旨在提供抵御空中攻击的保护伞的雷达，以及克里米亚塞瓦斯托波尔的大型军事基地。

;

;乌克兰拥有的射程最远的导弹是英国提供的鱼叉导弹和风暴阴影导弹。两者的最大航程都远远低于新罗西斯克及其接近距离。这将使乌克兰打击该地区油轮的努力变得复杂。

;

;乌克兰还开发了少量威力较弱的远程无人机，这些无人机可能被用于五月份对莫斯科的象征性袭击。

;

;由于缺乏可部署的海军，基辅一直在使用水面无人机攻击俄罗斯海军舰艇，其中大部分都被炮火挫败。只有海军护航才能为俄罗斯商船提供此类防御。

;

;英国向乌克兰发射远程“风暴之影”巡航导弹

;

;伦敦智库国际战略研究所海军和海上安全高级研究员尼克·柴尔兹(Nick Childs)表示，“他们以多种方式表明，他们可以以令俄罗斯人惊讶的方式使俄罗斯航运受到威胁，因此他们有可能做到这一点。”

;

;“问题是这是否是言辞的一部分正如我们过去所看到的那样，俄罗斯人可能还认为，夜间对乌克兰港口和粮食码头的袭击，再加上威胁攻击商业航运，足以造成事实上的封锁，而不必实际击沉任何船只。

;

;对满载油轮的袭击还会带来环境灾难的风险，这可能会引发国际社会不必要的强烈反应.

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 01:50:02 +0800 China, fed up with US sanctions, is hitting back with export controls – and more could comehttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3228220/china-fed-us-sanctions-hitting-back-export-controls-and-more-could-come?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.21 00:30;
;;

;我记得第一次遇到出口管制是在2011年，我参观了北爱尔兰的一家精密仪器公司。首席执行官告诉我，中国对其产品有巨大的未满足需求。但由于担心因违反英国政府的出口管制措施而被罚款甚至入狱，他的公司不得不放弃了这个商机。

;

;在此后的四年里，作为中国驻伦敦大使馆的最高经济和商务外交官，我一次又一次听到类似的抱怨。

;

;不过，英国并不是唯一实施出口管制的国家。许多政府利用它们来履行对多边组织的义务，并确保国内工业的原材料供应。

;

;西方政府实施了世界上最详尽、最广泛的出口管制措施，通常是出于意识形态或地缘政治目标。 1949年，美国牵头成立多边出口管制协调委员会，以对抗共产主义。它的后继者瓦森纳安排，除了军火清单外，还列出了一长串军民两用商品和技术，从电信到航空航天和推进装置。

;

;自1949年“红色中国”诞生以来，中国一直是西方出口管制措施的主要目标。冷战期间，限制向中国出口的产品比向苏联出口的产品还要多。 2007年华盛顿对中国的管制清单包括飞机及其发动机、光纤、先进导航系统、激光器和贫铀。近年来，华盛顿在这份清单中加入了新兴技术和基础技术，例如 4G 半导体材料、先进电子计算机辅助设计 (ECAD) 软件和网络安全。

;

;尽管对中国实行普遍的出口管制制度和全面的出口限制，但华盛顿及其一些西方盟友最近在中国决定控制其镓和锗出口时表达了担忧。拜登政府甚至表示“坚决反对”北京的决定。这种反应是西方双重标准的典型——用中国网民的话来说，就是自己放火，而别人却连一盏灯都没有。

;

;镓和锗是典型的两用商品。这些利基金属用于5G通信、电动汽车和可再生能源行业，还用于制造军事系统，例如F-35战斗机上的先进雷达。

;

;中国意识到家门口不断升级的挑衅行为所带来的威胁，例如军舰和战机侵入其领海，以及以中国为假想敌的军事演习。在如此恶劣的环境下，向对手提供用于制造武器的矿物就等于递给他们刀子。当然，像任何其他国家一样，中国也不希望其对手能够利用其产品来对付自己。

;

;即便如此，北京的新许可制度是为了控制出口，而不是彻底禁止。中国似乎并不打算切断这两种利基金属的供应；据其贸易部称，符合要求的出口申请将获得批准。

;

;国际商业界可以预期这两种金属的供应将继续，只要它们用于“合法目的”。虽然中国没有对此进行定义，但可以适当解释为：不用于军事用途。

;

;中国始终关注全球供应链的安全与稳定，并表现出维护全球供应链安全与稳定的意愿。 2020年，当欧盟考虑以国家安全为由将华为技术排除在欧盟5G网络之外时，中国于当年6月决定将提供5G设备的合同授予诺基亚和爱迪生，这令许多西方人感到惊讶。这一决定使欧洲企业增加了在中国市场的份额。

;

;中国的最新举动表明其对西方制裁的态度越来越强硬。正如中国向西方学习的那样，其出口管制很可能将单向轨道变成双向道路。

;

;中国多次警告华盛顿无情打压其高科技行业的后果，并明确表示维护自身利益的决心。尽管这基本上只是说说而已，但中国现在看起来更愿意言出必行，并利用贸易工具来捍卫自己的利益。

;

;5月份，北京禁止该国关键基础设施运营商从美国芯片制造商美光科技购买产品。可能会采取更多行动。其新的出口制度很可能是一个预兆。

;

;中国对镓和锗的出口管制并不是对特定行动的报复，例如荷兰政府决定限制向中国出口先进芯片制造机器，而是对华盛顿及其西方盟友（在较小程度上）的总体敌意的回应。通过将中国作为对手，华盛顿迫使北京进行反击。

;

;如果中国对美国和西方发动保护主义贸易战怎么办？

;

;几十年来，美国一直能够从中国获得所需的镓和锗。但这种情况正在改变。华盛顿在这两种关键矿产方面的脆弱性和不安全性很可能会增加而不是减少，至少在短期和中期是这样。华盛顿的中国遏制战略正在取得成效。

;

;事实是，在我们这个相互联系的世界里，所有国家都生活在玻璃房子里。我们应该极其谨慎地扔石头，这样做不仅会损坏别人的房屋，还会损坏我们自己的房屋。

;

;

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 00:50:01 +0800 US Chinatowns are shrinking, and while some want to fight, new ones are springing uphttps://www.scmp.com/economy/global-economy/article/3228357/us-chinatowns-are-shrinking-and-while-some-want-fight-new-ones-are-springing?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.21 00:00;
;;

;在美国最古老的中资企业中心旧金山唐人街，该地区的餐饮场所、礼品店和药草摊上都挂满了空置标志。

;

;在奥克兰旧金山湾对面的唐人街，猖獗的店面涂鸦和对抢劫的恐惧让路边杂货店日常的喧嚣变得冷漠起来。

;

;商品蚂蚁正试图逃离这两个地方——以及全国大部分地区的老唐人街。

;

;然而，在旧金山湾区的圣莱安德罗郊区，市中心的一个购物中心内有六家中国主题餐馆和一家茶吧。

;

;奥克兰唐人街正在慢慢从 Covid-19 关闭和反亚裔攻击中恢复过来

;

;一家名为“香港厨师”的餐厅仅在两个月前开业。另一家自助餐 Fortuna 分发的名片上有一个被划掉的奥克兰地址，就在目前圣莱安德罗店的旁边，该店很快就赢得了良好的声誉。

;

;香港厨师值班经理 Ruby Bo-yi 表示，该餐厅至少在晚上 9 点之前对游客来说是安全的，并补充说有很多中国人来就餐。

;

;餐厅没有涂鸦，并允许在大型停车场免费停车，这与旧金山街头停车位稀缺或昂贵的情况不同。

;

;

;

;附近的都柏林、弗里蒙特和山景城郊区正在兴起自己的迷你唐人街，这些唐人街往往进一步受到附近其他亚洲人美食的影响。

;

;奥克兰唐人街商会会长 Carl Chan 表示：“因素有很多。”

;

;“相比之下，去圣莱安德罗这样的城市更容易。做生意的成本并没有那么昂贵。”

;

;美国大部分地区正在形成新的唐人街，通常是因为与历史悠久的中国商业活动中心相比，犯罪率较低，租金也较低。

;

;大约 200 个或更多的老唐人街仍然作为新中国移民的社交和商业中心，其中一些可以追溯到 100 多年前。

;

;在纽约，曼哈顿的旧中国商业区已将其部分重心转移到法拉盛” 18 个城市的唐人街团结运动联合牵头组织者 Brian Pang 表示。

;

;“人们的动力是离开唐人街，所以我们看到唐人街正在萎缩。它肯定会失去吸引力。”

;

;彭的团队于五月在温哥华召开了一次会议，探讨重塑或振兴历史悠久的唐人街的方法。

;

;正是在那些像村庄一样的地区，移民仍然居住在联排别墅或时尚联排别墅的商店上方。

;

;他们可能会在点心餐馆、面碗摊贩和杂货店中找到华人诊所、保险机构和私立学校——仅举几个标志。

;

;但在俄勒冈州波特兰市，42 岁的邓肯·黄 (Duncan Hwang) 在富邦购物中心 (Fubonn Shopping Center) 购买一些食物。该购物中心位于第 82 大道沿线一个蓬勃发展的新兴地区，这里有中国人和越南人经营的企业。

;

;黄是区域规划机构都市委员会 (Metro Council) 的成员，就住在附近，他可以轻松地将车停在外面的大型购物中心停车场，购买火锅油以及主流杂货店找不到的其他商品。

;

;“我认为这是一个购买杂货并找到充足停车位的好地方，”台湾裔黄说。

;

;同一条大道上还有另一个亚洲大型市场，中餐馆分布在两条大道之间。每年夏天，附近都会有一个夜市，开车即可到达一家亚洲健康诊所。

;

;波特兰的第一个唐人街建于二战后，现在只剩下一座大门和一座苏州风格的花园。

;

;黄说，它的最后一家餐馆是一家面馆，大约两年前关门了。该地区从来没有超市，也没有无限的免费停车场。

;

;2020年，来自邻近破败地区的无家可归者也开始在人行道上搭帐篷，对购物者形成威慑。

;

;但长期观察人士表示，大多数老唐人街不太可能消亡。

;

;奥克兰唐人街商会会长陈表示，奥克兰的中心以其珍珠奶茶和午夜后咖啡馆吸引着年轻的中国人。

;

;商人表示，年轻的华裔通常更喜欢在郊区而不是城市唐人街购物。

;

;陈补充说，尽管该市其他地方呼吁取消资金，商会仍不断敦促奥克兰市议会做出改变，并敦促警方加大力度。

;

;陈补充说，在奥克兰做生意的成本已经损害了该地区 400 家商户中的一些。

;

;“在唐人街，每人 99 美元。”住在这里、在这里工作、在这里做生意的人有百分之一需要警察，所以我开玩笑说，如果你不想警察，就派他们去唐人街吧。”陈说。

;

;“我想我们很多人都不愿意放弃。”

;

;傅宏基的红宝石王面包店尽管在他的奥克兰唐人街大楼外有涂鸦，偶尔有一家用木板封起来的商店，店主仍然担心遭到破坏，但仍然有源源不断的顾客来购买咖啡和蛋挞。 .

;

;这位广州人经营这家面包店已近 30 年，但他承认，由于盗窃和抢劫，唐人街正在“萎缩”。

;

;“很多商人只是说算了，”他说。 “年轻人，如果他们必须来的话，他们就会来。”

;

;他预测，如果事情得到清理，奥克兰将会反弹。

;

;“从现在开始的未来 10 年，如果安全性良好且足够干净，那就没问题了，”傅补充道。

;

;在旧金山，主厨 George Chen 领导了一个耗资 2000 万美元的项目，开设了他的四层楼美食八桌餐厅综合体。

;

;Hong Kong authorities have warned thousands of homeowners they face prosecution for failing to complete inspections or repair works on their buildings on time, but surveyors say legal action will lack a deterrent effect if penalties are not increased.

;

;The government issued the warning on Thursday following a spate of incidents of concrete falling off buildings this month, including two cases that resulted in injuries. Authorities also revealed that owners of 2,700 old buildings had not completed mandatory inspections within their deadlines.

;

;“If the owners' corporations or owners neglect the Mandatory Building Inspection Scheme notices leading to poor progress, the Buildings Department will take enforcement actions and initiate prosecutions in a strict manner,” the Development Bureau said.

;

;Hong Kong man hurt by falling concrete, the second victim hit by debris in 3 days

;

;It said that while some buildings served with such notices had already taken follow-up action, the relevant work was delayed because of the pandemic in recent years, and weather had worsened the deterioration of external walls.

;

;Arthur Cheung Man-to, chairman of the building surveying division of the Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors, said the existing penalties were too low.

;

;“The government still has room to increase the penalties … It can bring a higher deterrent effect,” he said.

;

;Under the mandatory inspection scheme, owners' corporations of buildings aged 30 years or older must appoint a registered inspector within three months of receiving a statutory notice, carry out a review within six months and the repairs within a year.

;

;Over half of Hong Kong buildings with inspection notices have yet to be checked

;

;Anyone who fails to comply faces a maximum fine of HK$50,000 and one year's imprisonment. Offenders must also pay HK$5,000 for each day the order is not carried out.

;

;Cheung said the government could take reference from the penalties targeting unauthorised works. While the maximum jail time is also a year, the maximum fine is HK$200,000 and offenders are also charged HK$20,000 a day until illegal structures are removed.

;

;“Owners have a responsibility to repair and maintain their properties. The government can further work on ways to assist them,” Cheung said, suggesting for example that the assessment time for various repair subsidy schemes could be cut.

;

;Director of Buildings Clarice Yu Po-mei earlier this month said the government would review whether there was a need to raise penalties against non-compliance.

;

;According to government figures, 2,700 buildings have failed to comply with orders before their deadline, with 1,300 of those not completing repairs on time and 500 still undergoing checks.

;

;Another 150 blocks have yet to appoint a registered inspector but are taking part in “Operation Building Bright 2.0”, a repair subsidy programme launched by the Urban Renewal Authority in 2018.

;

;Concrete chunks fall off Hong Kong building, hitting Mercedes-Benz on road below

;

;The government said it would urge the relevant registered inspectors and building owners to expedite their work and report their progress within a month.

;

;“If one's progress is unsatisfactory without reasonable excuse, depending on the circumstances, the department will instigate prosecution proceedings to the owners' corporation or relevant owners by the end of this year,” it said.

;

;The bureau said that for the remaining 750 buildings that had yet to hire inspectors, it would invite them to join the subsidy programme while assessing their risks as soon as possible.

;

;“[We will consider] factors such as building conditions, potential risks to the public, whether it is facing [a] major traffic road … and arrange manpower for the use of drones to conduct special [surveys] on the external walls of buildings with higher risks,” it said.

;

;It added that it would carry out emergency repair works on behalf of owners if necessary. Owners will need to pay the cost plus an additional 20 per cent fee afterwards.

;

;The Buildings Department would also carry out inspections and repairs on another 1,100 buildings which were assessed to have higher risks, the bureau said.

;

;Hong Kong buildings authority under fire over falling concrete from block

;

;Lawmaker Vincent Cheng Wing-shun said the government should prioritise handling blocks that had failed to complete inspections for three years or more, in particular those for seven to nine years.

;

;He also called for an overall review on the issue of building repairs, such as looking at how to improve subsidy arrangements and streamlining inspection procedures.

;

;“The government has to explore ways to encourage owners' participation in repairing their buildings,” Cheng said, adding that the government should only conduct repairs on behalf of owners as a last resort.

;

;At least six debris-falling cases have been recorded within a month, with the latest incident injuring a man, 27, on Wednesday at the Lai Wan Building in Sai Wan Ho. An elderly woman was struck by mosaic tiles in Tai Po on Monday.

;

;In Mong Kok, two parked cars were slightly damaged by concrete pieces on Sunday, while another vehicle was hit by debris from an industrial building on Monday last week.

;

;Also in Mong Kok earlier this month, chunks of concrete also fell off a residential block twice in four days, prompting authorities to step up enforcement action against homeowners who fail to carry out mandatory inspections.

;China has ignored an invitation to attend a defence conference next month as it continues to rebuff American attempts to resume high-level dialogue between the two countries' militaries, according to a senior US admiral.

;

;Admiral John Aquilino, the head of Indo-Pacific Command, told The Aspen Security Forum in Colorado that attempts to contact his People's Liberation Army counterparts have been disregarded or declined, including a recent invitation to attend the annual chiefs of defence conference in Fiji next month, according to a Bloomberg.

;

;“We have invited, but we have not heard [back],” Auillino said.

;

;Zhou Chenming, a researcher with the Beijing-based Yuan Wang military science and technology think tank, said China had expressed concerns about Washington's promotion of closer ties with Taiwan, work with Asian allies to contain China and increased military reconnaissance near China's coastline.

;

;“However, Beijing feels that Washington has turned a deaf ear to those concerns, and the US navy continues its provocation by sending aircraft to fly over the Taiwan Strait,” Zhou said, referring to the flyover of a P-8A Poseidon last week.

;

;“China feels disheartened because senior US officials, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defence Lloyd Austin, all claimed that they don't want conflict between the two countries,” Zhou continued.

;

;US to blame for poor relations, Chinese defence minister tells Kissinger

;

;“But until now, Washington has not taken any steps to alleviate tensions such as lifting the sanctions against Chinese Defence Minister Li Shangfu.”

;

;Li was sanctioned in 2018 for his alleged role, as head of the PLA's Equipment Development Department, in securing the transfer of Russian jets and missiles to China.

;

;An academic from the PLA's Academy of Military Sciences contrasted the Aquilino snub with the warm welcome Beijing gave the former secretary of state Henry Kissinger this week, who met Li during the visit.

;

;“It's extremely rare for a Chinese defence minister to meet a former secretary of state, and I believe it was Kissinger who requested the meeting with Li, because he is trusted by the Pentagon to help push for the resumption of the dialogue with the PLA,” said the academic who spoke on condition of anonymity.

;

;Last month Li declined a request to meet Austin at the Shangri-La defence forum in Singapore, something the PLA blamed on the sanctions.

;

;Kissinger has visited China more than 100 times, state broadcaster CCTV reported on Thursday, including his secret trip to Beijing in July 1971, which paved the way for Richard Nixon's icebreaking visit to China the following year.

;

;But the scholar warned: “I'm afraid that Kissinger can't break the ice between the two militaries this time, as Washington has failed to keep its words about improving the bilateral ties as the two sides agreed to last November when Presidents Xi Jinping and Joe Biden met in Bali.”

;

;The meeting between Kissinger and Li followed one between Xie Feng, China's ambassador to the US, and Ely Ratner, US assistant secretary of defence for Indo-Pacific security affairs.

;

;“I think [the current situation] reflects the really terrible state of the relationship and Beijing's disinterest in actually improving it through dialogue,” said Drew Thompson, a visiting senior research fellow at the National University of Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy.

;

;The US is keen to resume high-level talks between the two militaries – which Beijing suspended last year in protest at a visit to Taiwan by then House speaker Nancy Pelosi – as a way of reducing the risk of misunderstandings.

;

;China says US must correct 'mistaken actions' before top defence chiefs meet

;

;Shi Yinhong, an international relations professor at Renmin University, said that Beijing no longer trusts Washington to reduce engagement with Taiwan and will not agree to normalise military relations as a result.

;

;“Beijing fears that the US will use it as an excuse to provide comprehensive support to Taiwan ranging from military, economic to diplomacy, encouraging the Taipei government to pursue independence freely,” Shi said.

;

;He added that China took efforts to prevent conflict seriously, but believes that is mainly down to front-line offices on both sides as well as “Washington's self-restraint capability”.

; Thu, 20 Jul 2023 23:50:03 +0800 Hong Kong teen who gave birth in school toilet, gagged baby with cloth and dumped her near rubbish bin spared jail after pleading guilty to infanticidehttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3228401/hong-kong-teen-who-gave-birth-school-toilet-gagged-baby-cloth-and-dumped-her-near-rubbish-bin-spared?utm_source=rss_feed

;A teenager has been spared jail for killing her newborn at a Hong Kong secondary school after a judge expressed sympathy with the defendant over her difficult upbringing and recognised her deep remorse for the crime.

;

;The teen, who cannot be identified due to a gag order, was instead placed on a year-long probation, where she will be required to receive psychiatric counselling and attend rehabilitative programmes as directed by the Social Welfare Department.

;

;She earlier pleaded guilty in the High Court to infanticide after suffocating her baby three years ago, saying she was under severe stress.

;

;Hong Kong judge signals she may not jail teen who killed newborn daughter

;

;Madam Justice Susana D'Almada Remedios on Thursday said the accused had received little care or guidance from her divorced parents during the critical development years.

;

;“This case is truly a tragedy to both the defendant and the deceased baby,” the judge said. “Having considered all circumstances in this case, the defendant's background and her mental condition, I am of the view that the defendant is not in need of punishment but of rehabilitation.”

;

;The defendant was in Form Six when she gave birth inside a school toilet in the middle of a sports lesson on September 22, 2020.

;

;To prevent the baby's cries from being heard, she gagged her with a piece of cloth, put her inside a bag and hid her in an empty room.

;

;She returned to class but left school early with the bag that afternoon. She abandoned the bag next to a rubbish bin on her way home.

;

;The baby was dead by the time a passer-by discovered her in the early hours of the following day. An autopsy concluded she died of asphyxia.

;

;Prosecutors accepted the girl's plea to a lesser count of infanticide in lieu of murder after two psychiatrists agreed she was significantly disturbed by the baby's unexpected birth, and she had yet to fully recover from the continued bleeding and pain when she committed the crime.

;

;The court heard the defendant began living with her father and twin sister in a run-down village house after her parents separated when she was four years old.

;

;Woman who threw newborn in bin walks free from Hong Kong court

;

;But she had had very little communication with her only guardian who would spend the entire day at work, forcing her and her sibling to learn to be self-reliant “the hard way”.

;

;The family's living conditions were deplorable, according to social workers following their case, as their stone house was filled with rubbish and inhabited by cockroaches and rats.

;

;The defendant moved out to live with her mother, after the latter remarried in mainland China and returned to the city with a son from the new marriage.

;

;But the mother and son returned to the mainland in early 2020 at the outset of the Covid-19 pandemic, leaving the defendant living alone in a flat while her twin sister stayed with their father.

;

;The girl became pregnant during a time when classes were being taught online due to the pandemic.

;

;A probation officer remarked in a pre-sentencing report the teen developed self-loathing due to her crime.

;

;Defence counsel Christopher Grounds said his client felt “tremendous contrition” for what she had done and was prepared for a jail sentence should the court find it appropriate.

;

;“This is a social problem, if one looks at the lack of parental care and circumstances surrounding the defendant,” the lawyer said. “She has unnecessarily taken too much responsibility onto herself.”

;

;Hong Kong woman gets 2 years' probation in 'unfortunate' case of infanticide

;

;Remedios said she believed the girl could receive sufficient rehabilitation, having heard from the defence counsel the father was now in better accommodation.

;

;A probation order could also help the defendant's psychiatric condition improve, the judge said, noting the teen still experienced depressive episodes from time to time.

;

;Infanticide, the killing of a child under one year of age, carries the same penalty as manslaughter, with a maximum sentence of life imprisonment.

;

;But custodial sentences are extremely rare, as ruled by the High Court in a 2015 case, with probation orders generally favoured in recognition of the defendants' need for support and supervision rather than punishment.

;;

;The head of American semiconductor giant Micron Technology has visited China and met with the Ministry of Commerce, according to a local media report, two months after the Chinese cyberspace regulator banned sales of its products to certain mainland clients.

;

;State-controlled Chinese newspaper National Business Daily reported that Micron President and CEO Sanjay Mehrotra met the Beijing official on Wednesday, without giving further information about the discussion. Micron did not respond to a request for comment about the report.

;

;The report did not mention whether Mehrotra had met with other Chinese government agencies, including the Cyberspace Administration of China, which imposed the Micron sales ban in May.

;

;If confirmed, the visit would be another indication that American chip companies are reluctant to give up on the Chinese market, despite rising US-China geopolitical tensions.

;

;Intel's CEO Patrick Gelsinger concluded a low-key trip to China last week as his company pushes its latest processor for artificial intelligence (AI) deep-learning applications, the Gaudi2, a device that is not currently covered by US export restrictions.

;

;China chip industry group urges US not to impose further restrictions

;

;According to memory chip maker Micron, a quarter of its revenue comes from Hong Kong and companies headquartered in mainland China. After Beijing's sudden ban, Micron said it would maintain communications with the Chinese authorities. The following month, it announced plans to invest 4.3 billion yuan (US$600 million) to upgrade its chip packaging plant in Xian, the capital of central Shaanxi province.

;

;Chinese authorities said in late May that the US memory chip giant had failed to pass a cybersecurity review, and prohibited the sale of its products to China's critical information infrastructure operators (CIIOs), which include a wide range of entities from telecoms operators to banks and water utilities.

;

;While Micron's spending in Xian is modest compared to plans to invest US$3.6 billion in Japan, and even the US$825 million it is spending on a new test facility in India over the next few years, Mehrotra said the move showed its commitment to its China operations and the local team.

;

;Other US chip makers have recently reaffirmed their desire to continue doing business in China in the face of reports that the Biden Administration is mulling an expansion of existing chip restrictions on national security grounds.

;

;Earlier this week, the main US semiconductor trade association, which includes Micron and Intel as members, cautioned Washington against further “overly broad” and “ambiguous” restrictions on exports to China, warning this could undermine existing legislation such as the Chips and Science Act.

;

;Micron has said that it will work to mitigate the impact of China's ban, with only a low double-digit percentage of revenue estimated to be at risk. Some of China's top server makers, including Inspur Group and Lenovo Group, have already moved to suspend shipments containing Micron chips.

;

;In the first quarter of this year, Micron's revenue dropped 57 per cent amid the tough conditions in the global chip market, although the performance nevertheless beat expectations.
